thread.title: Portland's 90-day notice rule has renters' and landlords' attention
thread.title_full: Portland's 90-day notice rule has renters' and landlords' attention | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Theen | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Portland's 90-day notice rule has renters' and landlords' attention
text:
Portland declared a housing emergency this month, but the City Council's new rules requiring landlords to give tenants 90 days' notice when raising their rents or evicting them won't go into effect until Nov. 13.
Commissioner Dan Saltzman, who oversees the Housing Bureau, said he thought the city needed to give landlords time to spread the word and, and 30 days seemed fair.
But with Portland's red-hot rental market, including rents rising at an annual rate of 14 percent , some worry the lag time could lead landlords to increase rents now.
"That is a legitimate concern," Saltzman said. "There is room to game the system."
The City Council approved the rules Wednesday. Starting Nov. 13, landlords must give tenants at least 90 days' notice for no-cause evictions or when they plan to raise rent 5 percent or more. The rules apply to tenants on month-to-month leases.
The rules don't apply to week-to-week renters or those renting a room in a landlord's home; those tenants get 30 days' notice if they've been in the home less than a year, 60 days' if longer.
Landlord organizations and renter advocates were still processing the changes Thursday.
"It's definitely going to be challenging to get this information out to everyone that needs to know about it," said Deborah Imse, executive director of Multifamily Northwest, which represents landlords.
Imse said her organization, which includes 400 members who manage 10 or fewer units , would send an alert Thursday afternoon. Portland has 100,000 to 125,000 rental units, including homes and apartments, Imse said.
Justin Buri, executive director of the nonprofit Community Alliance of Tenants, said volunteers will monitor the agency's already-busy hotline to see what renters say.
"We certainly hope that landlords would not be pre-emptively issuing evictions or rent increases to avoid a longer notification period," Buri said, adding that he doesn't expect many to do that.
